Award.AwardTitle: Prognostic Methods for Battery Management Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to develop prognostic methods for improving the safety and availability of battery-powered systems such as electric vehicles and unmanned aerial vehicles. Battery-powered systems suffer from two problems. The first is "range anxiety" problem, which refers to the fear of running out of battery power during vehicle operation. The second problem is related to the safety of a battery pack, which can rupture or even explode under certain conditions. To address these problems, an approach for predicting the (1) end-of-discharge (the time at which a battery will run out of electrical charge), and (2) remaining-useful-performance of a battery with a known level of confidence will be developed. This approach involved machine learning algorithms to address future loading conditions, unit-to-unit variations, and modeling uncertainties.

This research will improve the operation readiness and safety of battery-powered systems that are used in applications ranging from commercial (electric vehicles) to defense (unmanned aerial vehicles) sectors. In 2011, President Obama announced his goal of having one million electric vehicles on the road by 2015. The proposed research will make significant contributions to reaching this target, since it can ease user concern about the safety and reliability of electric vehicles by providing robust battery state and health information in real-time, thus encouraging their widespread use. As a result, it will also decrease US dependence on foreign oil and reduce the emission of greenhouse gases. The content of this research will assist in the advancement of prognostics and health management techniques which will be disseminated to the engineering community through online graduate courses, seminars, workshops, and short courses thereby benefiting people from academia, industry and the military.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As lithium-ion batteries transition into more advanced applications including electric vehicles, advanced battery management strategies need to be developed and employed to insure the safety and reliability of battery powered systems. As a result of funding from the National Science Foundation, our group has developed novel control strategies and reliability estimation models for advanced lithium-ion battery applications.

Batteries are sensitive to temperature and can exhibit changes in performance and reliability based on its ambient environment. To address these coupled effects, we developed a machine learning model to estimate the battery’s state of charge at a wide range of temperatures and dynamic usage conditions. The neural network-based model can estimate the amount of energy stored in the battery at any given time based solely on measurements of the battery’s voltage, current, and temperature. When developing models, it is important for the model to be generalizable for a wide range of battery chemistries, and it shouldn’t overfit the data. Another outcome of our work is an efficient Unscented Kalman Filtering (UKF) algorithm that can be combined with a battery model to reduce the level of noise in the model prediction.

Traditionally, battery health is defined as a reduction in the capacity that it can store. As the battery undergoes life cycle stresses, its storage capacity reduces, eventually reaching a point when it can no longer meet its required function. Unfortunately, it is difficult to actually measure capacity in actual usage conditions due to partial battery discharge and dynamic operating conditions including regenerative braking. Another outcome of our work is a feature fusion methodology that allows us to define a health indicator that relies on multiple measurable battery parameters. By collecting data during the controlled charging profile of a battery including the constant current charge time, constant voltage charge time, as well as the battery’s internal resistance, we were able to develop a robust health indicator. Using prognostic methods developed in our group, we can project this health indicator into the future to predict the likelihood of failure and the most likely time of failure.

A third outcome of the research is a preliminary understanding of the role of structural measurements and battery state of charge. Prismatic and pouch Lithium-ion batteries experience a thickness change as they are charged and discharged. As a result of the change of thickness, the battery casing undergoes mechanical strain. Using surface mounted strain gauges, we were able to use strain along with voltage, current, and temperature to estimate the battery’s state of charge. We also explored the potential for strain gauges to detect permanent structural changes as a result of gas generation and electrode warpage.

As part of the work effort, we generated a significant amount of battery life cycle data for a wide range of operating conditions. This data has been made available to other researchers in academia and industry to enable open communication and innovation in the realm of battery management. Many other researchers have already utilized our data to publish new ideas in lithium-ion battery modeling. We have further disseminated our research findings through a graduate level course in prognostics and health management, conference presentations, webinars, and published journal articles.
